On the Practicality of Differential Privacy in Federated Learning by Tuning Iteration Times

Yao Fu, Yipeng Zhou, Di Wu, Shui Yu, Yonggang Wen, and Chao Li Yao Fu and Di Wu are with the Department of Computer Science, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, 510006, China, and Guangdong Key Laboratory of Big Data Analysis and Processing, Guangzhou, 510006, China (E-mail: fuyao7@mail2.sysu.edu.cn; wudi27@mail.sysu.edu.cn). Yipeng Zhou is with the Department of Computing, FSE, Macquarie University, Australia, 2122 (E-mail: yipeng.zhou@mq.edu.au). Shui Yu is with the School of Computer Science, University of Technology Sydney, Australia (E-mail: Shui.Yu@uts.edu.au). Yonggang Wen is with the School of Computer Science and Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore (E-mail: ygwen@ntu.edu.sg). Chao Li is with Tencent Technology (Shenzhen) Co. Ltd, China.(E-mail: ethancli@tencent.com).
Abstract

In spite that Federated Learning (FL) is well known for its privacy protection when training machine learning models among distributed clients collaboratively, recent studies have pointed out that the naive FL is susceptible to gradient leakage attacks. In the meanwhile, Differential Privacy (DP) emerges as a promising countermeasure to defend against gradient leakage attacks. However, the adoption of DP by clients in FL may significantly jeopardize the model accuracy. It is still an open problem to understand the practicality of DP from a theoretic perspective. In this paper, we make the first attempt to understand the practicality of DP in FL through tuning the number of conducted iterations. Based on the FedAvg algorithm, we formally derive the convergence rate with DP noises in FL. Then, we theoretically derive: 1) the conditions for the DP based FedAvg to converge as the number of global iterations (GI) approaches infinity; 2) the method to set the number of local iterations (LI) to minimize the negative influence of DP noises. By further substituting the Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms into the derived convergence rate respectively, we show that: 3) The DP based FedAvg with the Laplace mechanism cannot converge, but the divergence rate can be effectively prohibited by setting the number of LIs with our method; 4) The learning error of the DP based FedAvg with the Gaussian mechanism can converge to a constant number finally if we use a fixed number of LIs per GI. To verify our theoretical findings, we conduct extensive experiments using two real-world datasets. The results not only validate our analysis results, but also provide useful guidelines on how to optimize model accuracy when incorporating DP into FL.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Differential Privacy, Convergence Rate, Model Accuracy.

I Introduction

In the past decade, machine learning models have demonstrated unprecedented data processing capability in numerous applications. To well train machine learning models, it is unavoidable to massively collect data samples from users, which gives rise to the concern on user privacy leakage [1, 2]. This concern has significantly hindered the wide application of machine learning techniques. In light of this, Federated Learning (FL) [3] has been proposed to allow decentralized clients to collaboratively train machine learning models by merely exchanging intermediate computations (i.e., gradients) with the parameter server (PS). Raw data samples are locally kept on clients. However, it has been pointed out that the leaked gradient information can still be exploited by malicious entities to crack user privacy [4, 5, 6, 7, 8].111Users are used interchangeably with clients in this paper. To further enhance the protection of user privacy, Differential Privacy (DP) has been employed to add additional noises to client gradients before they are uploaded to the PS [9, 10, 11].

Unfortunately, the adoption of DP may lower the model accuracy significantly, which has become a major obstacle for the application of DP in FLÂ [9, 10, 11]. Taking the popular FedAvg algorithmÂ [3] as an example, the naive adoption of DP in FedAvg may cause 222-101010 times training loss than the original modelÂ [10]. For many real-world applications, such high performance deterioration can significantly reduce the effectiveness of advanced machine learning models, and is somewhat unacceptable at all. As FedAvg represents a large family of gradient descent (GD) based algorithms widely used in FL, it is questionable how practical DP will be when being applied to FL.

Typically, clients and the PS in FL works together with the following manner: clients conduct a number of local iterations (LI) before their gradients plus DP noises are uploaded to the PS for aggregation. By receiving the computations from multiple selected clients, the PS conducts a round of aggregation and distributes new results to clients for the next round of global iteration (GI) [12]. Apparently, it is only necessary to add the DP noises to clientsâ€™ gradients after the last round of LIs before they are disclosed to the PS. The noises distort the disclosed gradients against attacks, which meanwhile impair the convergence of FL [10, 11, 13].222Note that clients may have different privacy budgets and are independent in noise generation [14, 15]

In this work, we investigate how to improve the practicality of DP in FL through tuning the number of conducted local or global iterations. Intuitively, we can improve the model accuracy if the number of LIs is tuned properly since there is no need to add noises after each LI except the last LI. Firstly, we derive the convergence rate of the FedAvg algorithm distorted by the DP noises. Secondly, we derive the conditions for the DP based FedAvg to converge, and formally derive the formula to set the number of LIs according to the DP mechanism to minimize the negative influence of DP noises. At last, we conduct case study by using the Laplace mechanism and the Gaussian mechanism, through which we theoretically unveil that: 1) The learning error of the DP based FedAvg with the Gaussian mechanism can finally converge to a constant number if we use a fixed number of LIs per GI; 2) The DP based FedAvg with the Laplace mechanism will diverge with the number of GIs, but the divergence rate can be lowered substantially by setting the number of LIs according to our method.

Overall, our contributions in this paper can be summarized as below:

  • â€¢

    To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to theoretically study the practicality of DP in FL through tuning the numbers of LIs and GIs, which paves the way towards a better understanding of the complicated relation between the random noises introduced by DP and the final FL model accuracy.

  • â€¢

    We formally derive the convergence rate of FedAvg with DP noises and the convergence conditions. By substituting the Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms into the convergence rate, we theoretically investigate how to optimally tune the number of LIs and GIs so as to minimize the influence of DP noises.

  • â€¢

    Extensive experiments with real-world datasets are conducted to validate the correctness of our theoretic results, and demonstrate the practical merit of our work, which provides us a way to optimize the FL model accuracy even if DP is adopted.

The rest content is organized as follows. The related state-of-the-art works are discussed in Sec. II. The preliminary knowledge is introduced in Sec. III. The DP-FedAvg algorithm is elaborated in Sec. IV. The derivation and optimization of the converge rate of DP-FedAvg are presented in Sec. V. The experiment results are presented and explained in Sec. VI before we finally conclude our paper in Sec. VII.

II Related Work

II-A Federated Learning

The FL framework was originally proposed in the works [3, 16, 17], which applied FL on mobile devices to predict the next word of mobile usersâ€™ text input. Both FedAvg and FedSGD algorithms used for neural network based models were empirically studied with extensive experiments inÂ [3]. Later on, the convergence rate of FedAvg/FedSGD was analyzed in [18] with non-IID data sample distributions.

Since the inception of FL, it has attracted tremendous attentions. Kairouz et al.Â [12] and Li et al.Â [19] conducted a holistic overview of FL with in-depth technical discussions on possible weaknesses of FL. It has been proved that FL can improve the protection of user privacy to some extent [12]. However, the leakage of the gradient information can still result in the leakage of user privacy, which can be exploited by malicious users to design various attack strategies [4, 5, 6, 7, 8].

II-B Differential Privacy

Other than FL, DP is another widely adopted approach to preserve user privacy [20]. The principle of DP is to add noises to individual usersâ€™ private information before it is disclosed. Consequently, malicious attackers cannot exactly crack usersâ€™ private information even if the information is leaked. Thanks to its ability for preserving privacy, it has been applied in personalized recommendation systems [21], location based services [22], meta learning [23] and so on. However, the shortcoming of DP is that the service quality will be lowered because service providers cannot obtain precise user information as well [9, 10, 24].

II-C Applying DP in FL

DP can be applied to machine learning such as FL to enhance the privacy protection level. In FL, there exist two schemes to add DP noises: the global DP scheme and the local DP scheme. The former one adds noises to the aggregated gradient information on the server side before the gradient information is distributed to clients [13, 25]. Whereas the latter one adds noises to the gradient information on users before it is uploaded to the server [9, 26, 27, 28].

There are many existing works [29, 13, 25] that targeted to design mechanisms to add global DP noises in machine learning systems such as FL. For example, the work [13] particularly focused on using DP to mask whether a client participates in the training (i.e., client-level DP).

Prior works on the incorporation of LDP are elaborated as follows. Wu et al. [10] theoretically analyzed the convergence performance when local DP is used in a distributed learning system. Only the gradient descent algorithm is considered in this work, and its analysis proved that the GD algorithm can converge if the sample population approaches infinity, which however is impossible in practice. In addition, the scenario considered in this paper is not a typical FL setting, and the influence of the non-IID sample distribution is ignored. Wei et al. [11] considered both global DP and local DP in an FL system. Their theoretical analysis validated that the number of global iterations and the number of engaged clients in each global iteration should be neither too large nor too small to minimize the final loss function. However, only the FedSGD algorithm with IID sample distribution was mentioned in this work, which was not consistent with an FL scenario. The analysis of the FedAvg algorithm and the influence of the number of local iterations were absent in the above work.

Other than the above LDP mechanism that can guarantee the privacy budget over all rounds of global iteration, there exist a number of other works that designed and analyzed a loose LDP mechanism that can only guarantee the privacy budget for a single round of global iterationÂ [9, 28, 30]. For example, Seif et al. [28] relaxed the local Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP in wireless FL settings, which gave fixed noises in each iteration and used advanced composition rule to track the total privacy leakage over Tğ‘‡T iterations. However, the privacy leakage will increase to infinity with Tğ‘‡T, though they can obtained a converged upper bound finally.

In summary, prior works have demonstrated that it is promising to incorporate DP into FL. However, how to minimize the negative influence of the noises incurred by DP has been overlooked by existing works. Especially, how to set up the number of LIs and how it affects the final model accuracy have not been explored yet, and this gap will be filled by our work.

Before we introduce our algorithm, we list the symbols and notations used in this paper, as shown in TableÂ I. Some ofthem will be defined later in the following sections.

In FedAvg, each client updates the model on the local dataset ğ’Ÿlsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘™\mathcal{D}_{l} for Eğ¸E epochs, following the rule:

III-B Differential Privacy

Both FedAvg and FedSGD assume that the PS can be trusted and clientsâ€™ privacy cannot be cracked through gradient information. However, such assumptions are not always valid [6, 5, 7, 8]. Thereby, the DP technique is introduced to add noises to gradients generated by clients before their gradients are aggregated.

We briefly introduce the essential concepts in DPÂ [20, 31] before we introduce how to incorporate DP into FedAvg.

Definition 1 ((Ïµ,Î´italic-Ïµğ›¿\epsilon,\delta)-Differential Privacy).

A randomized function ğ””ğ””\mathfrak{Q} gives Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-differential privacy if for any data sets ğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ1\mathcal{D}_{1} and ğ’Ÿ2subscriptğ’Ÿ2\mathcal{D}_{2} differing on at most one entry, and all ğ’®âŠ†Râ€‹aâ€‹nâ€‹gâ€‹eâ€‹(ğ””)ğ’®ğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ””\mathcal{S}\subseteq Range(\mathfrak{Q}),

Prâ¡{ğ””â€‹(ğ’Ÿ1)âˆˆğ’®}â‰¤expâ¡(Ïµ)Ã—Prâ¡{ğ””â€‹(ğ’Ÿ2)âˆˆğ’®}+Î´.Prğ””subscriptğ’Ÿ1ğ’®italic-ÏµPrğ””subscriptğ’Ÿ2ğ’®ğ›¿\Pr\left\{\mathfrak{Q}(\mathcal{D}_{1})\in\mathcal{S}\right\}\leq\exp(\epsilon)\times\Pr\left\{\mathfrak{Q}(\mathcal{D}_{2})\in\mathcal{S}\right\}+\delta.

The traditional Laplace mechanism gives (Ïµ,0)italic-Ïµ0(\epsilon,0)-DP, while the Gaussian mechanism gives (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP. By tolerating some possibility of fails (represented by Î´ğ›¿\delta), the Gaussian mechanism performs better on the utility under composition. We will introduce detailed Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms later. For generality, we use â„³â„³\mathcal{M} to denote the noise generator of DP mechanisms.

IV-B DP Mechanisms

The DP mechanism determines how to set ğ°tlsuperscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘™\mathbf{w}_{t}^{l} on each client before the updated model is returned to the server. In this work, we consider two most frequently used mechanisms (i.e., Laplace and Gaussian) in the convergence analysis. In fact, other DP mechanisms can be substituted into our framework as well by setting ğ°tbsuperscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğ‘\mathbf{w}_{t}^{b} with a different form.

According to the composition rule of DP [31], we cannot consider the DP privacy budget for each iteration separately. To simplify our analysis, we define the asymptotic variance of the DP noise item as follows.

Definition 2.

The asymptotic variance of the noise item of a DP mechanism â„³â„³\mathcal{M} is defined as ğ•â„³=Oâ€‹(Î·~t2â€‹E2â€‹Tgz)subscriptğ•â„³ğ‘‚superscriptsubscript~ğœ‚ğ‘¡2superscriptğ¸2superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”ğ‘§\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{M}}=O(\tilde{\eta}_{t}^{2}E^{2}T_{g}^{z}), where zâˆˆ[0,2]ğ‘§02z\in[0,2] is a constant number determined by the DP mechanism.

In the definition of the asymptotic variance, all variables not related with the number of LIs or GIs are regarded as constant numbers and ignored. We define ğ•â„³subscriptğ•â„³\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{M}} based on the fact that Î·~t2â€‹E2superscriptsubscript~ğœ‚ğ‘¡2superscriptğ¸2\tilde{\eta}_{t}^{2}E^{2} affects the function sensitivity, while Tl=bNâ€‹Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”T_{l}=\frac{b}{N}T_{g} represents the number of GIs each client needs to participate. Meanwhile, we let 0â‰¤zâ‰¤20ğ‘§20\leq z\leq 2 because the privacy budget at most increases linearly with Tlsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™T_{l} according to the composition rule.333According to the composition rule in the DP theory, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP will be at most Tlâ€‹Ïµsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™italic-ÏµT_{l}\epsilon-DP if the database is queried for Tlsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘™T_{l} times.

This is a very generic definition that can depict most existing DP mechanisms devised for FL, such as [10, 11]. The asymptotic variances of the noise items of the Laplace and Gaussian mechanisms introduced as above can be obtained as

ğ•Laplace=Oâ€‹(Î·~t2â€‹E2â€‹Tg2).subscriptğ•Laplaceğ‘‚superscriptsubscript~ğœ‚ğ‘¡2superscriptğ¸2superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”2\mathbb{V}_{\textit{Laplace}}=O(\tilde{\eta}_{t}^{2}E^{2}T_{g}^{2}). (2)
ğ•Gaussian=Oâ€‹(Î·~t2â€‹E2â€‹Tg).subscriptğ•Gaussianğ‘‚superscriptsubscript~ğœ‚ğ‘¡2superscriptğ¸2subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”\mathbb{V}_{\textit{Gaussian}}=O(\tilde{\eta}_{t}^{2}E^{2}T_{g}). (3)

Obviously, how to set Eğ¸E and Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”T_{g} will affect the variance of the noise item, and hence it will affect the convergence of DP-FedAvg. Meanwhile, we note that the asymptotic variance of the Gaussian mechanism is lower than that of the Laplace mechanism, and therefore the Gaussian mechanism can yield a better convergence rate. We conduct the convergence analysis of DP-FedAvg in the next section.

V Convergence Analysis of Client Based DP-FedAvg

In this section, we give the theoretic analysis of the convergence of FedAvg when DP mechanisms are applied on the client side.

V-A Definitions and Assumptions

In FL, it is well-known that the distribution of data samples is non-IID, that is, the training data samples of different clients may be drawn from distinct distributions. By leveraging the measure of the degree of non-IID inÂ [18], we define the degree of non-IID as below.

Definition 3.

The degree of non-IID is quantified by

Lemma 3 (Bounding the divergence of local parameters).

Let AssumptionÂ 3 hold, the expectation of the average distance between Î¸Â¯ksubscriptÂ¯ğœƒğ‘˜\bar{\theta}_{k} and Î¸klsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘˜ğ‘™\theta_{k}^{l}â€™s is

The detailed proof of LemmaÂ 1 is presented in Appendix. The proof of LemmaÂ 2 andÂ 3 can be found inÂ [18]. LemmaÂ 4 can be proved by modifying the proof of inÂ [18] a little bit. The proof of TheoremÂ 3 leverages LemmasÂ 1, 2, 3 and 4, which can be found in the Appendix with details.

V-C Asymptotic Analysis

To focus on the influence of iteration times, we conduct asymptotic analysis of the convergence rate by regarding all variables not related to the LI or GI as constant numbers.

V-C1 Convergence Conditions

The convergence rate derived in TheoremÂ 3 can be simplified as

YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡\displaystyle Y_{T} =\displaystyle= Oâ€‹(E2T)+Oâ€‹(Ï‰1Eâ€‹T),ğ‘‚superscriptğ¸2ğ‘‡ğ‘‚subscriptğœ”1ğ¸ğ‘‡\displaystyle O\left(\frac{E^{2}}{T}\right)+O\left(\frac{\omega_{1}}{ET}\right), (4)
=\displaystyle= Oâ€‹(E2T)+Oâ€‹(E1âˆ’zâ€‹Tzâˆ’1).ğ‘‚superscriptğ¸2ğ‘‡ğ‘‚superscriptğ¸1ğ‘§superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§1\displaystyle O\left(\frac{E^{2}}{T}\right)+O\left(E^{1-z}T^{z-1}\right).

Here, we utilize the fact that Ï‰1=Oâ€‹(E2â€‹Tgz)subscriptğœ”1ğ‘‚superscriptğ¸2superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”ğ‘§\omega_{1}=O(E^{2}T_{g}^{z}) and Eâ€‹Tg=Tğ¸subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”ğ‘‡ET_{g}=T is the total number of iterations. Through Eq.Â (4), we prove the convergence conditions of DP-FedAvg as follows.

Theorem 4.

YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} of the client based DP-FedAvg with the mechanism â„³â„³\mathcal{M} will converge to 00 as Tğ‘‡T approaches infinity, if z<1ğ‘§1z<1 in ğ•â„³subscriptğ•â„³\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{M}}. The number of LIs should be set as E=Oâ€‹(Tzz+1)ğ¸ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§ğ‘§1E=O(T^{\frac{z}{z+1}}) to achieve the fastest convergence rate Oâ€‹(Tzâˆ’1z+1)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§1ğ‘§1O(T^{\frac{z-1}{z+1}}).

Proof.

We first prove the convergence conditions. From the first term in Eq.Â 4, we have E<Oâ€‹(T)ğ¸ğ‘‚ğ‘‡E<O(\sqrt{T}), otherwise the first term will diverge. Thus, for the second term we have Oâ€‹(E1âˆ’zâ€‹Tzâˆ’1)<Oâ€‹(T1âˆ’z2+zâˆ’1)ğ‘‚superscriptğ¸1ğ‘§superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§1ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡1ğ‘§2ğ‘§1O(E^{1-z}T^{z-1})<O(T^{\frac{1-z}{2}+z-1}). It converges only if 1âˆ’z2+zâˆ’1<01ğ‘§2ğ‘§10\frac{1-z}{2}+z-1<0 which implies that z<1ğ‘§1z<1.

Then, we prove the optimal value of Eğ¸E is Oâ€‹(Tzz+1)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§ğ‘§1O(T^{\frac{z}{z+1}}). Since YT=Oâ€‹(E2T)+Oâ€‹(E1âˆ’zâ€‹Tzâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡ğ‘‚superscriptğ¸2ğ‘‡ğ‘‚superscriptğ¸1ğ‘§superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§1Y_{T}=O(\frac{E^{2}}{T})+O(E^{1-z}T^{z-1}), it is a convex function with respect to Eğ¸E. By letting the differentiation of YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} with respect to Eğ¸E equal to 00, we have Oâ€‹(ET)+Oâ€‹(Eâˆ’zâ€‹Tzâˆ’1)=0ğ‘‚ğ¸ğ‘‡ğ‘‚superscriptğ¸ğ‘§superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§10O(\frac{E}{T})+O(E^{-z}T^{z-1})=0. It turns out that we should set E=Oâ€‹(Tzz+1)ğ¸ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§ğ‘§1E=O(T^{\frac{z}{z+1}}). âˆ

Theorem 5.

YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} of the client based DP-FedAvg with the mechanism â„³â„³\mathcal{M} cannot converge to 00 as Tğ‘‡T approaches infinity, if zâ‰¥1ğ‘§1z\geq 1 in ğ•â„³subscriptğ•â„³\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{M}}. The number of LIs should be set as E=Oâ€‹(Tzz+1)ğ¸ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§ğ‘§1E=O(T^{\frac{z}{z+1}}) to minimize the influence of the DP noise item, which gives rise to the lowest divergence rate Oâ€‹(Tzâˆ’1z+1)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§1ğ‘§1O(T^{\frac{z-1}{z+1}}).

Proof.

From the proof of TheoremÂ 4, we can see that YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} cannot converge if zâ‰¥1ğ‘§1z\geq 1.

Similar to the proof of TheoremÂ 4, we should set E=Oâ€‹(Tzz+1)ğ¸ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§ğ‘§1E=O(T^{\frac{z}{z+1}}) to achieve YT=Oâ€‹(Tzâˆ’1z+1)subscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§1ğ‘§1Y_{T}=O(T^{\frac{z-1}{z+1}}). However, due to zâ‰¥1ğ‘§1z\geq 1, YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} will diverge with the minimum rate Oâ€‹(Tzâˆ’1z+1)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§1ğ‘§1O(T^{\frac{z-1}{z+1}}) as Tğ‘‡T approaches infinity. âˆ

Corollary 5.1.

If z>1ğ‘§1z>1 in ğ•â„³subscriptğ•â„³\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{M}}, there exists a Tâˆ—<âˆsuperscriptğ‘‡T^{*}<\infty that can minimize YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T}.

The proof is straightforward given that YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} is a convex function with respect to Tğ‘‡T and YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} will diverge if z>1ğ‘§1z>1. Unfortunately, it is extremely difficult to precisely derive Tâˆ—superscriptğ‘‡T^{*} due to the difficulty to exactly estimate the value of each parameter such as Î¼ğœ‡\mu, Î“Î“\Gamma and GğºG in YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T}.

V-C2 Case Study

For the Laplace and the Gaussian mechanisms, they are the special cases of our general analysis. For the Laplace mechanism, we have z=2ğ‘§2z=2, which implies that the Laplace mechanism can never converge. The divergence rate can be minimized by setting Eğ¸E as an increasing function of Tğ‘‡T. According to the TheoremÂ 5, we should set E=Oâ€‹(T23)ğ¸ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡23E=O(T^{\frac{2}{3}}) and YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} will diverge with the lowest rate Oâ€‹(T13)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡13O(T^{\frac{1}{3}}) as Tğ‘‡T approaches infinity.

Remark: We can see the significance of our study from This case study. If we set E=Oâ€‹(1)ğ¸ğ‘‚1E=O(1) for the Laplace mechanism, YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} will diverge with the rate Oâ€‹(T)ğ‘‚ğ‘‡O(T), which is much higher than the optimal rate Oâ€‹(T13)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘‡13O(T^{\frac{1}{3}}). Thus, setting Eğ¸E properly with our method can markedly improve the practicability of DP in FL.

The DP based FedAvg with the Gaussian mechanism is a very special case. According to the TheoremÂ 5, YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} cannot converge to 00. However, if we set E=Oâ€‹(1)ğ¸ğ‘‚1E=O(1), YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} will converge to Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) as Tğ‘‡T approaches infinity.

VI Experiment

In this section, we carry out extensive experiments with two real-world datasets to validate our theoretical analysis.

VI-A Dataset Description and Preprocessing

VI-A1 Lending Club Dataset

The Lending Club datasetÂ [10] contains about 890,000890000890,000 loan data records. Each record in the dataset includes some features of borrowers (e.g., zip code, address, request amount of money, and interest rate).

The dataset is used to predict customersâ€™ interest rates. We first clean the data by discarding meaningless features (e.g., ID, address, and job title). Then we convert some valuable text features to numbers, such as job year and grade. We discard those features missed by more than 70%percent7070\% of data records. After the above preprocessing operations, there remain 666666 features, though some features are redundant and some are almost always 00. We use Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to further reduce 666666 features into 101010 effective features. In the experiments, we use randomly sampled 500,000500000500,000 data records as the whole dataset. And then we randomly sample 80%percent8080\% data as the training dataset and the rest as the test dataset. To setup the non-IID distribution, all records in the training dataset are sorted by the interest rate in ascending order before they are evenly grouped into N=5,000ğ‘5000N=5,000 groups. Each client will be assigned a single sample group.

VI-A2 FEMNIST Dataset

FEMNIST is an open source dataset presented inÂ [35] as a benchmark for FL study. FEMNIST contains 803,267803267803,267 hand-written image samples written by 3,50035003,500 users. There are 626262 labels (i.e., 101010 digits, 262626 lowercase, 262626 uppercase) in the dataset. We use 90%percent9090\% samples to train the model and the rest as the test set. Because FEMNIST is naturally unbalanced and non-IID, we simulate 3,50035003,500 clients and assign each client with a userâ€™s samples.

VI-B Models and Experimental Settings

We construct a Linear Regression (LR) model with 111111 parameters for the Lending Club dataset to predict the interest rate of each borrower. Mean Square Error (MSE) is used to define the loss function and evaluate the model prediction performance.

For the FEMNIST dataset, we construct a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model to classify images. The CNN model consists of two convolutional layers followed by one fully connected layer. The first convolution layer uses 7Ã—7777\times 7 kernels with padding 333. The second layer uses 3Ã—3333\times 3 kernels with padding 111. The first layers has 323232 channels while the second has 646464 channels. Both convolutional layers are followed by a ReLU and 2Ã—2222\times 2 max pool. The fully connected layer has 626262 units and takes the flatted output of the second convolutional layer as the input. The CNN model contains 214,590214590214,590 parameters. CrossEntropy is used to define the loss function.

In the experiments, we use the MSE loss function and the model accuracy on the test datasets to evaluate the LR model and CNN model, respectively. We can evaluate the model performance over the test set after each round of global iteration. If E>1ğ¸1E>1, the model is only evaluated when kâˆˆğ’Eğ‘˜subscriptğ’ğ¸k\in\mathcal{C}_{E}.

For each case, we implement a benchmark model, which is a special case with Ïµ=âˆitalic-Ïµ\epsilon=\infty, i.e., there is no DP noise. To get rid of the influence of the randomness due to random noises and random client selection in ECPs, we plot the average results by executing each experiment case for 202020 times. By default, we set b=500ğ‘500b=500 for the LR model and b=350ğ‘350b=350 for the CNN model.

We impose the Laplace mechanism on the LR model and the Gaussian mechanism on the CNN model. Throughout the following experiments, we set a fixed Î´=0.0001ğ›¿0.0001\delta=0.0001 for the Gaussian mechanism.

In practice, it is very difficult to exactly compute the sensitivity, i.e., Î¾ğœ‰\xi, of the gradient functions, and thus we use the norm clipping technique with a clipping threshold Î¶ğœ\zeta to restrict the range of clientâ€™s gradients. If a clientâ€™s some gradient exceeds Î¶ğœ\zeta, it will be clipped to Î¶ğœ\zeta. Formally, the gradient is clipped by

âˆ‡flâ€‹(Î¸k)=âˆ‡flâ€‹(Î¸k)/maxâ¡(1,â€–âˆ‡flâ€‹(Î¸k)â€–1Î¶),âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘™subscriptğœƒğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘™subscriptğœƒğ‘˜1subscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘™subscriptğœƒğ‘˜1ğœ\nabla{f}_{l}(\theta_{k})=\nabla f_{l}(\theta_{k})/\max\left(1,\frac{\left\|\nabla f_{l}(\theta_{k})\right\|_{1}}{\zeta}\right),

where we set Î¶=150ğœ150\zeta=150 for LR model and Î¶=3ğœ3\zeta=3 for CNN model. This technique is firstly introduced by [29] and widely used in the implementation of DP in practical machine learning systems [25, 13].

VI-C Results and Discussions

In this part, we present the results of our experiments.

VI-C1 Impact of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon

To inspect the influence of the privacy budge on the model training process, we conduct experiments by enumerating different Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€™s. For the LR model, we set T=100,E=1formulae-sequenceğ‘‡100ğ¸1T=100,E=1 and Ïµ=1.0,3.0,5.0italic-Ïµ1.03.05.0\epsilon=1.0,3.0,5.0 or âˆ\infty; while for the CNN model, we set T=250,E=5formulae-sequenceğ‘‡250ğ¸5T=250,E=5 and Ïµ=10.0,20.0,30.0italic-Ïµ10.020.030.0\epsilon=10.0,20.0,30.0 or âˆ\infty. Note that we set relatively large Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€™s for the CNN model due to the large number of parameters in CNN. Similar Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€™s were also used in other works such asÂ [11, 10].

The loss function of the LR model is obtained on the test set of the Lending Club dataset. In Fig.Â 1, we can observe that there exists a gap between the loss function curves with DP noises and the loss function curve with Ïµ=âˆitalic-Ïµ\epsilon=\infty. In particular, the loss function diverges rapidly when Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is very small. It shows the challenge to make DP based FL practical, especially when the privacy budget is small.

The accuracy of the CNN model evaluated on the FEMNIST test set is plotted in Fig.Â 2 against the iteration times. In Fig.Â 2, we can draw a similar conclusion that the model accuracy can be impaired by the DP noises significantly such that implementing DP in FL is challenge when Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is small.

VI-C2 Impact of Tğ‘‡T

We conduct experiments to verify TheoremÂ 5, which states that: 1) YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} approaches infinity as Tğ‘‡T increases and there exists some Tâˆ—<âˆsuperscriptğ‘‡T^{*}<\infty such that YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} is optimized if the Laplace mechanism is adopted; 2) YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} converges to Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) as Tğ‘‡T approaches infinity if the Gaussian mechanism is adopted.

In Fig.Â 3, we evaluate the LR model using the Lending Club dataset and the Laplace mechanism by varying Tğ‘‡T from 00 to 100100100 with a step size 101010 and set E=1ğ¸1E=1. We plot the loss function YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} against Tğ‘‡T. Note that YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} is different from Yksubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜Y_{k} where YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} is the final loss after Tğ‘‡T iterations and Yksubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜Y_{k} is the loss after kğ‘˜k iterations. We also show the accurate value of Tâˆ—superscriptğ‘‡T^{*} and the corresponding loss in TableÂ II. As we can see that the loss function diverges finally as Tğ‘‡T increases. For each experiment case, there exists some Tâˆ—superscriptğ‘‡T^{*} such that the minimum value of the loss function is achieved.

For the CNN model, we use the FEMNIST dataset for evaluation by varying Tğ‘‡T from 00 to 500500500 with a step size of 505050 and E=5ğ¸5E=5. As shown in Fig.Â 4, the model accuracy gets stable at some value as Tğ‘‡T approaches infinity per the Gaussian mechanism is adopted. This result implies that YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} approaches Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) instead of diverging to infinity as Tğ‘‡T approaches infinity.

VI-C3 Impact of Eğ¸E

We conduct experiments to show the importance to tune Eğ¸E, i.e., the number of local iterations, in DP-FedAvg.

We enumerate different Eğ¸Eâ€™s to see how Eğ¸E can affect the model training process. In Fig.Â 5, we evaluate the LR model using the Lending Club dataset and the Laplace mechanism, by enumerating E=1,2,3,4,6,12ğ¸1234612E=1,2,3,4,6,12 and fixing T=120ğ‘‡120T=120 with different Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€™s. Similarly, in Fig.Â 6, we evaluate the CNN model by fixing T=240ğ‘‡240T=240 and enumerating E=1,2,3,4,6,8,12,24ğ¸1234681224E=1,2,3,4,6,8,12,24 with different Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€™s. To accurately show the optimal Eğ¸E, we list the results in Fig.Â 5 and Fig.Â 6 in TableÂ III and TableÂ IV.

Through observing Fig.Â 5 and Fig.Â 6, we can draw the following observations.

  • â€¢

    In both Fig.Â 5 and Fig.Â 6, for all cases with different Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€™s, if Eğ¸E has not been set properly, the performance of the trained model can be very poor. For example, the loss function of the LR model is very high if E=1ğ¸1E=1 when Ïµ=1.0italic-Ïµ1.0\epsilon=1.0. This experiment manifests the importance to tune Eğ¸E in DP based FL.

  • â€¢

    Eğ¸E should be neither too large or too small. Intuitively, if Eğ¸E is too large, it means Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”T_{g} will be too small and the model training process is not iterated sufficiently. Inversely, if Eğ¸E is too small, it means Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”T_{g} is too large, and hence the model training process can be impaired by the large DP noises. Recall that ğ•â„³=Oâ€‹(Î·~t2â€‹E2â€‹Tgz)subscriptğ•â„³ğ‘‚superscriptsubscript~ğœ‚ğ‘¡2superscriptğ¸2superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”ğ‘§\mathbb{V}_{\mathcal{M}}=O(\tilde{\eta}_{t}^{2}E^{2}T_{g}^{z}).

  • â€¢

    Through comparing cases with different Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonâ€™s in both figures, we can find the rule of thumb that Eğ¸E should be set a larger value if Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is smaller.

To verify TheoremÂ 4, we conduct the experiment by using the Lending Club dataset and the Laplace mechanism. In this experiment, we set Eğ¸E as a function of Tğ‘‡T. Specifically, we enumerate E=1,T13,T12,T23â€‹Â orÂ â€‹Tğ¸1superscriptğ‘‡13superscriptğ‘‡12superscriptğ‘‡23Â orÂ ğ‘‡E=1,T^{\frac{1}{3}},T^{\frac{1}{2}},T^{\frac{2}{3}}\textit{ or }T by varying Tğ‘‡T from 111 to 120120120 with a step size of 101010. Note in this experiment, we set b=5000ğ‘5000b=5000 to enable very small Tgsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”T_{g} (i.e., Tg=1subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘”1T_{g}=1). If Eğ¸E (as a function of Tğ‘‡T) is not an integer, it will be rounded to the nearest integer. According to TheoremÂ 4, it is optimal to set Eâˆ—=T2/3superscriptğ¸superscriptğ‘‡23E^{*}=T^{2/3}. The result is presented in Fig.Â 7, which indeed confirms the correctness of our theoretical analysis. The curve with E=T23ğ¸superscriptğ‘‡23E=T^{\frac{2}{3}} is the best one achieving the lowest loss function. Although, YTsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘‡Y_{T} will diverge with the increase of Tğ‘‡T, its divergence rate is very low if E=T23ğ¸superscriptğ‘‡23E=T^{\frac{2}{3}}. Another important implication is that the setting of Tğ‘‡T is not very sensitive if Eğ¸E is chosen properly.

VII Conclusion

We investigate the practicability of DP mechanisms in FL. A general DP based FedAvg algorithm is presented first. Then, both the Laplace mechanism and the Gaussian mechanism are introduced into the general DP based FedAvg algorithm. Through tuning the number of local/global iterations, we show from both theoretical analysis and experimental study that it is very important to set the number of iteration times properly such that the influence of the DP noises can be minimized. Specifically, via defining the asymptotic variance of the DP noises, we derive the conditions for DP-FedAvg to converge, and the optimal choice of the number of local iterations. The Lending Club and FEMNIST datasets are utilized to conduct extensive experiments. The experiment results not only verify our theoretical analysis, but also demonstrates that the choice of the number of local iterations can heavily affect the model training performance.

Appendix E Proof of LemmaÂ 1

Proof.

Taking expectation, we obtain

ğ”¼â€‹{Î½Â¯kb}=Nbâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹{âˆ‘lâˆˆğ’«tnlnâ€‹Î½kl}=Nbâ€‹âˆ‘ğ’«âˆˆÏ•bâ€‹(ğ’©)1câ€‹(âˆ‘lâˆˆğ’«nlnâ€‹Î½kl),ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğœˆğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ”¼subscriptğ‘™subscriptğ’«ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘›ğ‘™ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘˜ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ’«subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ğ’©1ğ‘subscriptğ‘™ğ’«subscriptğ‘›ğ‘™ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœˆğ‘˜ğ‘™\begin{split}\mathbb{E}\left\{\bar{\nu}_{k}^{b}\right\}&=\frac{N}{b}\mathbb{E}\left\{\sum_{l\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\nu_{k}^{l}\right\}\\ &=\frac{N}{b}\sum_{\mathcal{P}\in\phi_{b}(\mathcal{N})}\frac{1}{c}\left(\sum_{l\in\mathcal{P}}\frac{n_{l}}{n}\nu_{k}^{l}\right),\end{split} (5)
